commentBody: Nice debut, congratulations!
There's no rebus!
Looks daunting with those long crosses, but just keep plugging along and it will all fall into place.
Fabulous puzzle. Difficult in parts but slowly gives way...

On xwordinfo.com, Jim Horne notes:
My dictionary defines audacious as "debuting on a Friday with two triple-stacks."

I quite agree.
Nice one, Caroline.
Glad you tried a themeless.
Congratulations to Caroline Hand on her fabulous debut!  Can‚Äôt wait to see more of her work.
I love spanners!

A good puzzle with some nice entries (looking at you APERCU) and some nice misdirections in the clues (bear up for URSA). As a reformed lawyer I loved suit material for TORT. Antediluvian for OLDASDIRT was worth a chuckle too. The bottom triple stack came fairly quickly for me, but the top stack was tougher.  I wanted stonewashed or acid rinsed to pair with denim, and having madd instead of SADD, delayed me in spotting SACAGEWEADOLLAR.
A stellar debut, chock full of spanners, misdirects, wordplay. Thoroughly entertaining!

Even though it was fast, I still enjoyed it because it was a good mental workout. Lately, if there are six spanners like this one has, it seems to be an excuse for it not taking too long.

Overall, a fun puzzle.

Fully concur with the constructor notes-  definitely in the Robyn Weintraub school of puzzle construction and there can be no greater compliment than that. 

I enjoyed the solve but do have one minor nit to pick with the editing- several clues/fill were rather US-centric (more than usual I felt) and I assume some overseas solvers may struggle with those.

I don't usually deal very well with stacks but these worked for me today. The ANASTASIA STEELE is the only one that took a while. However, I spelled APERCU as APERGU and had PIG instead of TIC. That took a while to sort out as everything seemed to fit initially.

I had fun with this though. Loved OLD AS DIRT!

A very entertaining Friday that solved a bit faster than I thought it might. I think the idea of emulating Robyn Weintraub worked extremely well for you, as this was great for a first timer!

The triple stacks were impressive, and I was fortunate enough to find enough crosses both top and bottom to figure them out fairly readily. I do have to admit that having a rival school in the Little Apple made that last spanner a gimme. The "school" association likewise made SADD the best option there. I liked the misdirects with URSA and TORT. I did have to depend on crosses a few other spots, but I finally got it all filled in correctly.

Thanks, Caroline, and again, great debut!

Good, tough Friday.  Along with yesterday's fine offering, it feels as if the editors are trying to make up with us.

It's working.  :)

Some of this was a little easy, and I did finish quite quickly, but I'd say Hard overall.  Checking against XWStats...  Hmm they have it as Average at this (relatively early) writing.

ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
A five star puzzle. Loved it!

Always like it when a puzzle puts up solid resistance and then slowly and grudgingly cedes ground. 

Anastasia Steele! Not really a match for Madame Bovary, Anna Karenina or Molly Bloom, but I did enjoy reading 50 Shades for the magnificent prose. For instance:

"Desire pools dark and deadly in my groin."

"My inner goddess is doing the merengue with some salsa moves." 
"My inner goddess sits in the lotus position looking serene except for the sly, self-congratulatory smile on her face." 
"My inner goddess jumps up and down with cheer-leading pom-poms shouting yes at me." 
"My inner goddess looks like someone snatched her ice cream."

"Why is anyone the way they are? That's kind of hard to answer. Why do some people like cheese and other people hate it? Do you like cheese?"

"Her eyes are brown, like bourbon, but flat."

"Desire explodes like the Fourth of July throughout my body."

"'You. Are. Mine,' he snarls, emphasizing each word."

 "A small moan escapes my mouth as my insides melt and unfurl."

"'I do hope you're not overly fond of these p@nties.' He tears through them with his adept fingers, and they disintegrate in his hands."

"He laughs and then is distracted by his BlackBerry, which must be on vibrate because it doesn't ring."

"It feels like an eon has passed while I process all this, though in reality it is only a split second."

"What's eating him? Oh, myself probably..."

Enjoyed seeing SACAGAWEA DOLLAR here.

Lovely debut, thanks
Very enjoyable‚Ä¶ I once again confused stat and stet‚Ä¶ and I have no shades of grey knowledge at all.   Maybe now I‚Äôll keep stat and stet straight.

Hard doesn‚Äôt always mean slow.

The best puzzles, in my mind, are the ones that give you a real workout. Challenging long entries and interesting fill.

And somehow, you can still get through them in thirty minutes or less.

You finish with that quiet feeling of self satisfaction.

I think that‚Äôs the kind of puzzle that put Robyn Weintraub on many of our ‚Äúfavorite constructors‚Äù list.

This was a great one.
I highly recommend the award-winning HBO comedy series, Somebody Somewhere, set in MANHATTAN KANSAS. It's a true gem.
I wanted to comment for once but emus won't let me and I have no idea why. Why did I bother...

Congratulations, Caroline, on your admirable persistence and outstanding puzzle, crunchy yet doable and highly enjoyable. Thank you! Speakung of outstanding, here is the phenomenal funk bassist Marcus Miller laying down a BASS LINE in the studio: https://youtube.com/shorts/4kptIkmqZRg?si=t4_Jn6HIR2lA-7fI And here he is bringing down the house playing with D'Angelo (RIP), Eric Clapton, and David Sanborn: https://youtu.be/DMb8BhCXNs4?si=5K2DSMYS-Z6wKS1m
Now I‚Äôm craving Chinese food.

Loved it. Lots of big original fill with challenging vowel structures.

Cheers

Congratulations on your debut, Caroline. You really did channel Robyn here and I enjoyed it. I started with acidwaShed DENIM before DISTRESSED. And I had Chicago Illinois before MANHATTAN KANSAS üòÜ Loved the two triple stacks. As Jim Horne said, audacious!! This month has highlighted the jig and now the REEL. My daughter competed in Irish dance for eight years and these entries always bring me joy. https://youtu.be/WOz_bNVY7OA?si=ZnNKqdkHMLD8I3AU Thank you, Caroline. I hope to see more from you.

Wow, 20 years! That‚Äôs dedication, and it paid off. This was a worthy Friday for anyone and certainly a fabulous debut.  
And finally I feel the cluing was pretty up to par for a Friday. Maybe fewer really ARTFUL misdirects than I might prefer, but mostly pretty solid and interesting  entries and clues. I had to solve from the bottom up as the only spanner that came easily was RUNINTERFERENCE, especially after PRAM and MAUNA which were my first real footholds. I wasn‚Äôt really fooled by CESARIANS (except some confusion about the spelling) but I‚Äôm just not a drinker or a fashionista so even after I got PALEALE and DENIM I didn‚Äôt have the full entries; and once I got DOLLAR I knew SACAGAWEA if only I could have spelled
 it (yeah, JIRTHS?)
So, Caroline, you should be really proud and thanks for showing everyone out there that persistence and patience will finally pay off!

commentBody:
The week's not done but I've almost entirely forgiven the editors for last week.

Very strong debut and very Weintraubian.

Now make more!

(Kidding not kidding.)

APERCU:  last to fall and with an alphabet vowel run for the U.

Never heard of it and hope it's not destined to be an ORA for me.

Who knew I knew all that stuff?  Well, I didn't, but when crosses kept turning up mistakes, I had no choice but to figure it out.  From the top, when I was trying to figure out some bitcoin kind of answer and DOLLAR came muscling in, to the bottom, when another fill presumed to RUNINTEFERENCEf, I was starting to get TICked off.  I thought maybe a nice DRAFT of AMERICANPALEALE might calm me down, but instead I had a lovely glass of strawberry Ensure. (Yes, it's come to that.)

Neither my husband nor I could remember what APERCU meant, but I figured it must be right, since not a lot of English words end in U. (Oh right, that's not English.)

You constructed a tough puzzle, Caroline, but no look-ups were necessary, which is the way a really well-made Thursday crossword should be. I loved it. Thank you, and I hope your next one will be another doozy.
Hold on‚Ä¶ isn‚Äôt that CAESAREAN? First A is missing?  But otherwise great puzzle!!
The AIRBAG wasn't mandated until when?!?!!?!
The midi? Why isn‚Äôt it available?
Impressed myself by getting hazylittlething right off the bat.
I propose we call the crossword the Mici, so I can say I have done the ‚ÄòMini, Midi, Mici‚Äô

Hmmm... I got this in 21:40. That's less than my average time on a Wednesday. Maybe a bit easy? 

Still enjoyed the puzzle.
amazing debut bravo!  hit the sweet spot in every way grazie mille
Extremely US centric which goes against the NYT games crew repeatedly stating that they want their games to have global appeal.

Six spanners was indeed impressive! Well done, Ms. Hand. On the other, um, hand, this was my fastest Friday ever, and I thought the cluing could have been more challenging. On the third hand, maybe at this ripe old age I'm just getting better!
18 mins today vs. 50+ mins yesterday?  Hmm...

This was a quiz with a few puzzling clues. Very much ü´§ 

I liked URSA.  

But the spanners had one gettable from the clue and two factoids. Solvable but not particularly enjoyable. 

I congratulate the setter on their debut because that is an incredible achievement.

I don't think I've ever stared at so many entries where I had all but one letter and simply could not get that last letter, e.g. TI? for [Jerk].  

Just couldn't quite close it out cleanly because I was thinking it was SAgAGAWEA.   Once I checked the spelling, life got a lot easier.

I for one felt quite challenged, even though I seemed to be in the zone for a while.
Congrats on the very solid debut!!!!!
Not a fan of MRIS crossing with MAUNA, RONAN, and DEBI

Enjoyed learning about SACAGAWEA, but as a Brit, no way I could have got her first letter without a look-up given 1-down.

As your esteemed president would say, "SADD".

(But I actually enjoyed this puzzle a lot).
really outstanding! so glad the creator kept trying!

Graph paper and just flipping through a tome, haha. I remember those days. Our careers have tracked oppositely; I had some early success and now haven‚Äôt appeared in over 15 years. Ah well.

A little ‚ÄòNosowsky-esque‚Äô also, I‚Äôd say. Bravo!

This was harder than the average Friday puzzle for me, partly because of the six 15's (whose crosses were not pushovers), but also because the constructor kept things constantly fresh and innovative. I kept hoping it would be SACAjAWEA, not SACAGAWEA (shudder!), but no such luck.

That was a fun but intimidating grid at first glance. I started with mADD, which really held back SACAGAWEA for the longest time. I got APERCU and had a vague idea I'd seen it before in English, but I wasn't sure it was also an English word. Then I misspelled MAUNA and thought "it can't be kung poo chicken, can it?" And Chicago Illinois fit, as many of us know. 

Well done, Ms. Hand!

Loved this puzzle! Thank you, Caroline! The big open areas intimidate me but I just kept getting letters here and there. When I finally got (remembered) MANHATTANKANSAS things started to click. I hope y‚Äôall have a wonderful Friday!

There‚Äôs something about the conjunction of words at the top and bottom of this formidable debut that is faintly mind boggling. (eg. Sacageawa and pale ale or Manhattan and Anastasia, which makes me think of ‚ÄòSome Like it Hot‚Äô). Also Denim and ‚Äòold as dirt‚Äô. It may not themed, but it has interesting cross currents!
A very satisfying solve.  Had to look up APERCU afterwards - that C the last to drop.  Congrats on sticking with it and getting into the club.

What a terrific week of puzzles so far!  Today‚Äôs wide-ranging beauty, preceded by:

ROLE REVERSALS Monday, to 
"e.g.," Tuesday, to
BREAK DANCES Wednesday, to
ROMAN NUMERALS Thursday

Thank you, constructors and NYT team!

That was tough! What a Friday should be‚Ä¶. Can‚Äôt say I completed it as I had to guess a couple of times on the first letter of one across‚Ä¶. Never would‚Äôve got it‚Ä¶ never heard of sagac‚Ä¶ or whatever it is. 
But congratulations to the constructor‚Ä¶ felt so much meatier than the last few fridays‚Ä¶

Brava on the debut!

Dug my heels in with
acid waShED DENIM,
but otherwise a smooth and lovely solve.

Going to Europe in a few weeks.
Normally I'm a pseudo-vegan.
I rarely eat meat or dairy, but
like to try classic foods when I travel.

Should I go for the TARTARE or 
fois gras while in Paris?

Are they worth it?

I always love never-give-up backstories, so a success like this Friday themeless that‚Äôs well-liked (even by Rex Parker!), as a debut, after 20 years ‚Äì 20 years! ‚Äì of rejected submissions, well, that warms my heart and inspires my soul. Congratulations, Caroline!

This puzzle led me through food and drink, architecture, the arts, myth, sports, and more.  It pinged beauty in shorter answers such as ARPER√áU, TUREEN, and ARTFUL, and longer ones such as RUN INTERFERENCE, DISTRESSED DENIM, and OLD AS DIRT.

It presented, for me, swooshy fill-in areas for the ‚ÄúWhee!‚Äù, as well as effortful ones for brain happification. 

And some lovely serendipities.  A PuzzPair¬© of DRAFTS and FAN.  REEL to cap off two appearances of JIG this week.  STRESSED in the third spanner ‚Äì our language‚Äôs longest common-word semordnilap.

Simply a box lush with lovely.  Thank you for making this, Caroline, and thank you for sticking to your vision.

I don't think I've ever encountered the word "aper√ßu." Haven't heard it, haven't seen it in print. It figures that it entered the language during the era when throwing a random French word into your conversation was seen as cultured. It shot me down in flames.

Manhatten, Kansas was a gimme to me, though. It is the home of the American Institute of Baking, which is a training and research facility collectively set up by the entire US baking industry in the early twentieth century. I attended a sixteen week training session there during the fall and winter of 1993. I arrived there by bus from Atlanta, which allowed me to bring my bicycle along. When I wasn't studying large-scale bakery production methods I was zooming around snow-covered Manhatten on my bike. It's a nice, relatively small college town, and although I missed my wife and kids horribly I did enjoy my stay there.

I still tend to think of Kansas first, rather than New York, when I hear the word "Manhatten."

I breezed through most of the puzzle but the top stack held me back. I guess I didn't recognize CESAREAN because now it's called C-section. Years ago, when someone had a C-section, it was in the newspaper, i.e., Elizabeth Taylor. Now it is becoming more and more common. 

From Google:
"Brazil has one of the highest cesarean section rates globally, with approximately 55-57% of all births delivered surgically as of 2021-2022. While public health initiatives aim to reduce this, rates remain high, reaching over 80% in private hospitals. The trend is driven by high-income preferences, perceived convenience, medicalized childbirth culture, and fear of liability."

What a terrific constructor story!

I just love the exuberance.

I was as distressed as an American pale ale when I couldn‚Äôt find my error in SACAGAWEADOLLAR that obviously would be the thing causing my not-quite-thereness. Turned out I had RONiN by mistake.


Otherwise, a very enjoyable puzzle!
AWESOME Puzzle!

Wow, I had never heard of Sacagawea, even though I have seen the coins. I just thought of them as "those dollar coins with a Native American woman".

This made the top into a Natick infestation for me. My guess for 1D was MADD (admittedly, I had heard of SADD, just forgotten about it), for 2D I had EMIR (never heard the name AMIR), and for 7D, I had never heard of ACES either, but at least it's an English word, so it was the most plausible guess once I had ?CES.

I'm guessing people who grow up in the US might learn of Sacagawea in elementary school? (I grew up abroad.) I propose a solution: Disney should make a movie about her! (That's why I _do_ know Pocahontas :-)
Not Friday-hard, but such great fill and clever clues. Consistently enjoyable top to bottom.
Fantastic Friday Puzzle! A great big üëè to the constructor‚Äôs resilience.
I got all the English words easily apart from the proper nouns.
This is the type of Friday / Saturday puzzle I've been waiting to return.
Thought this was a good difficulty for a Friday, nothing overly esoteric but still took me a couple minutes to break into. APERCU was new to me
Fun puzzle! A confession: I saw that STONEWASHEDDENIM was one letter too long and wouldn't work for the SADD crossing, so I had DISHWASHEDDENIM for the longest time. Is that even a thing???

Yesssss. That's more like it!

Congrats on an excellent debut! I was shocked and then delighted to see all those spanners confronting me on a Friday. I had several moments of panic up north, trying to spell CESAREAN, APERCU, and SACAGAWEA. I wasn't too DISTRESSED, though, and I eventually got through it!

Wow! A lovely debut. Brava!
I'm with those who had mADD first. 
1A - So I was thinking "coinage" as in a phrase. "Mac-a-gave-a-dollar"? Never heard anyone say that. LOL
But I knew the v was a W. So in the end I cracked it.
TGIF
PS - am I the only one who has avoided Fifty Shades in all its forms? I got 57A only through the crosses and common sense.

Teams from The University of Evansville (Indiana) are The Purple ACES.  Those are the ones I know.  
I had CAESARIAN sections, not CESAREAN sections.  So there.
I would have thought the plural of NAAN is NAAN--a mass noun.
Porn books have heroines?  Ick.  (No, I haven't read it.  Not on my list, either.  Too many good books out there to waste time on junk sensations.)
Totally stumped on "The Little Apple" until the K appeared.  Hah.

Those are some serious stacks!!

Tough one! APERCU was new to me, and really hard to guess at. Wanted TUG for 22A which caused a real snarl in that part of the grid. Then there was my confidence that SACAGAWEA was spelled with a J rather than a G. Really didn't cover myself in glory today, but I'm going to go ahead and continue not using apercu in conversation :P

Love the challenge of all those spanners!
I was stuck at the end at 22a/9d & had to use my last ditch approach : going through the alphabet. Luckily ‚Äòc‚Äô made TIC b/c I have never heard of APERCU!

Brava for the debut!

to paraphrase Joyce Kilmer:

I think that I will never crack
A puzzle lovely as a stack!

Have I ever encountered one of these¬†I don't like?¬† I'm not sure I ever have -- and I certainly enjoyed this one.¬† Every time I was about to fall into the abyss, the puzzle threw me a lifeline.¬† Oh, was I happy to see some of the easy crosses.

A happy accident.¬† I had only the SUI for "adjoining in a way" and wrote in ENSUING.¬† This was completely wrong. but it gave me two correct letters I didn't deserve and helped me get to ENSUITE -- a much better answer.

Today I learned that there's a MANHATTAN, KANSAS.¬† You'd think that we residents of the pure, the true and, I assume, the original Manhattan would know about the existence of this other one.¬† And probably some of us do -- but I didn't.

A lovely stack puzzle, Carol, that's wonderfully free of junky fill.¬† Well done!
Persistence pays off, bigtime.  Congrats, Caroline, on a brilliant debut.

An intimidating looking grid that actually solved fairly smoothly, despite having no idea of 1A money, or the second MANHATTAN among others. I confess I only know SACAGAWEA from watching Night At The Museum 2 with my kids. (Why does my ipad want to put a J where the G is?)

Also, how do I know the name of 57A when I never read the book or saw the film?? I once glanced at my daughter‚Äôs copy, half a page was enough; how did such appallingly bad grammar, syntax and execution, let alone the trite subject, become a best seller? Has the ability of the reading public dropped so low? Gah.

Back to the puzzle. A good, enjoyable Friday. Brava to the constructor for persevering.
Apparently tit is not the answer for jerk. I need to stop watching so much British tv.
Brutal bottom fill.

Not only is there a Manhattan, Kansas, there is a Minneapolis, Kansas. 

This was a Good Friday with some long entries.  Got stuck in the northern parts, APERCU was a decent diversion. 

And of course I had ‚Äú@ss‚Äù for jerk initially. 

Thanks for a lovely puzzle, Ms. Hand.  We really gotta hand it to you with a round of applause.

26 down. You can find her in this clue (hidden).  ERIN 
What in the world does that mean?

I hope the editors are watching.
See how easy it is to make your base happy.

(Except for @Andrzej, who either complains about it being too easy or complains about it being too difficult.  The man SADDly has no Goldilocks-zone.
Sorry about the proper noun there, @A.)

I'll follow his shining example and give a few nits of my own:
More than a few too many gimmes, no?
Magna ____
____ de sac
our favorite Chinese general
Sri _____

Don't get me wrong.  I liked this puzzle quite well, and I might list my favorites and where I had problems (I'm looking at you ROKU!), but most of that has already been discussed here.
Okay, antediluvian.

This one was tough. I was fairly deep into the south before I had anything at all and then solved this pretty much SE to NW. Still even though I finished three minutes above my Friday average, I appreciated it as a wonderful challenge.
Love a puzzle with some long answers, very fun solve. Great debut, thanks Caroline!

Very tough one for me.  Second guessed a number of my answers after completing most of the Down entries along top.  Had never heard of Sacagawea.  A few others I was not familiar with then led to several look-ups.  Good puzzle, learned a few things today.

Whew. And Wow! Typical long Friday workout for me, but ended up being a quite enjoyable solve. And... this was one really impressive of construction. Making those grid-spanning triple stacks top and bottom has to be extremely difficult, and.. of all those answers - 

Two appearing for the first time. 
Two others that only appeared once before. 
One other that only appeared twice before, and..
one with 4 previous appearances and that was...
SACAGAWEADOLLAR
And all of those appearances were in the last 16 years. 

Wow. Just wow. 

Oh.. and my puzzle find. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

I would argue the question mark after 1-across was inappropriate, especially since the word uses are related. The question mark warns us, ‚ÄúThis might not mean what you think,‚Äù but in this case it was even odds‚Äîyou‚Äôd as likely think that coinage meant ‚Äúcurrency‚Äù as you would ‚Äúneologism.‚Äù  In my case, the apparent meaning read as ‚Äúcurrency,‚Äù so the question mark led me to try to find some early 2000s slang for the answer.
How fun to see my hometown and home to Kansas State Univ in this puzzle! It‚Äôs been the ‚ÄúLittle Apple‚Äù for a long time. Great place!

Before solving 1A and 16A, the 80s kid in me entered ACIDWASHEDDENIM for 17A. I wonder if the creator set that trap. 
Good puzzle!
Fast and fun.

That was a scary grid to look at at first but it all came together smoothly, very nice construction and impressive stacking of those long answers. I initially had "EFS" for Standoff's conclusion, though I guess "EFFS" would be proper spelling to make that answer work. I'd also started with PTS for the Carton amts, and had to scour the finished puzzle for my error to discover that of course IPTESTS aren't a thing, at least not as a measure of brightness. Mind your Ps and Qs!

Less than a minute (about 1%) slower than average.  The top three spanners, and the down crosses on the west side slowed me down.  Pretty typical Friday (timewise, at least) though I would have preferred the difficulty more evenly spread throughout the puzzle, rather than more concentrated in one spot.  But I understand that may have just been my experience, not that of anyone else.

I know people love to talk about how quickly they do they do these, but I‚Äôve been doing these for 60 years and I like when they take a little bit longer because I have to think. Whata terrific debut. Look forward to many more.
Nice work! I didn‚Äôt know what a TUREEN was until today. That‚Äôs what‚Äôs fun about crosswords ‚Äî sometimes, you get to learn!

Congratulations Ms Hand on your debut. 
I gasped slightly at the first sight of this grid and starting at the top left I had nothing. RUH ROH! Actually RUH was my first entry! Solving went quite smoothly from the top right and in a clockwise direction around the grid before finishing where I failed to start. Mainly because APERCU is unfamiliar to me and I couldn‚Äôt remember how to spell SACAGAWEA‚Äôs name.

Good one!
Sierra Nevada green-label has been my very favorite since 1990ish.
Sacagawea dollars are provided by the change machine at the local laundromat.
Before I remembered the Kansas college town I had filled in CHICAGOILLINOIS. *shrug*
Never ever seen APERCU.
Double dose of Chinese food!
What hurt me most was having ALERTS instead of DRAFTS.
GOOD 9NE.
Loved the punny theme in the Midi puzzle today!
Can we please not discuss the Midi in this comment section?

Oh, and one more puzzle find. A Sunday from April 18, 1993 by Norman S. Wizer with the title: "People with Connections." A couple of theme clue/answer examples: "Author, shore bird and actress." GEORGESANDPIPERLAURIE "Game-show host, stamp and statesman" MONTYHALLMARKANTONY And some other theme answers: GRANTWOODCHUCKCONNORS HARRYGOLDENRODSERLING EDITHHEADCOUNTBASIE JOHNBROWNBETTYBUCKLEY Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=4/18/1993&g=51&d=A ...

Wow I loved this and it looked daunting with the 3 stacks but was turned out to be so much fun! Last to fall: I had URSE as a guess for ‚ÄúBear up‚Äù because I got stuck on thinking it was a verb & of course had OLDeSDIRT instead of OLD AS DIRT which I guess was wishful thinking. Thank you ‚ò∫Ô∏è This was perfect after my abject scrabbling around yesterday which was also really fun! ü§©

I was very intimidated by the 6 spanners when I first opened the grid, and the first answer I entered (acidwashedDENIM) wasn't much help.

Thankfully (or unfortunately) I've read the "50 Shades" books, so at least that answer was correct.

I managed to muddle through it, and aside from a typo it took me a while to find, the hardest clue for me was 1A. Finally, with most of the crosses filled in, a faint memory of the coin in question came to me and yay! Happy music.  üòä

As the column mentions the pre-software days of crossword construction, I'd like to ask the puzzle creators and professionals among us about how much computing has changed the game. Has the frequency of great puzzles skyrocketed? Compared to that stone age, does the ease of puzzle-making generally now blow the minds of old-timers? And particularly with the advent of AI, is creating a crossword puzzle today simply a matter of asking for one?

There are a few creator names in these parts that are recognizable for consistently, outstandingly creative puzzles.  How much (if at all) does that reflect mastery of software on top of pure talent?

My first pass was a first-class disaster, beginning with 16A as HAZYLITTLETHING (the brewery's strong IPA) and ending with my confident entry for 58A CHICAGOILLINOIS. I was so chuffed at my brilliance in nailing the long crosses so knowingly.

In the end, there were a few I just never would have known, and I agonized over the spelling of a c-section, insisting on spelling Caesar's  name correctly.

On to Saturday.

I love a double triple stack! This was a great puzzle. I'm now at the point where I can usually solve a Friday quickly without any trouble, which is actually a bummer because I don't get to spend as much time enjoying it.
I had fun! Apercu got me. I quite liked erin though
Bravo!!!
I'm a little SADD because I had MADD.

Two in a row of excellent puzzles.  I had never heard of SADD (or some of the other trivia clues - who does the NYT Xword and has read 50 Shades?), but all the unknown trivia were answerable with wordplay cross-clues.  Please keep up the good work.

Overall a well-constructed puzzle, but I don't understand why the coinage clue had a question mark. What part of the clue was supposed to be misleading/tricky? "Coinage" is used all the time to refer to physical coins. It felt like the question mark itself was trying to mislead us by making us look for non-literal answers first. That nitpick aside, I enjoyed it!

APERCU is one of those words I've seen and resolved to look up later, but never did. I still don't really know what it means, but it seems like something you would say at a fancy cocktail party in ASTORIA...to illustrate a point. Oh, I think I've got it now.

I was scared with all the triple-stacks, but ended up with a personal best, about 15% off my previous time. 

Looking forward to more from Caroline Hand so I can determine whether it was a fluke.

Great puzzle, Caroline! Good morning for Greek mythology: on @Andrzej's recommendation, I recently read *Pandora's Jar*, Natalie Haynes' feminist reevaluation of the heroines of the Greeks; Ms. Haynes' encyclopedic knowledge of obscure Greek literature is rivaled only by that of a certain beloved Wordplayer. *Pandora's Jar* has chapters devoted to both Helen and Clytaemnestra, sisters hatched* from Leda's dalliance with SWAN-Zeus; and one on Medea, who hitched a ride from Colchis on the return trip of the ARGO. Here's J. & M.'s on-board meet-cute: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=40TSBMyfik8 Kurt and Bertolt know Raw: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7bEKU70_7E8 *Yes, hatched! Leda's children were Helen, Clytaemnestra, Castor, and Pollux. There are several variants of the myths, all of which include eggs--kinda weird, as Leda is human, not avian. In some variants, the children are paired off, Helen with Pollux, and Clytaemnestra with Castor, in two double-yolked eggs. In some versions, only Helen and Pollux are the children of Zeus, Clytaemnestra and Castor's father being Leda's mortal husband, Tyndareus, the result of some kinky mortal-divine menage a trois.

commentBody: @Rich in Atlanta As threatened: A Sunday from February 6, 2005 by Joel Kaplow with the title "What a picture is worth." Don't recall seeing another one quite like this. Some theme clues and answers: "10 cents" ROOSEVELT "$5000" MADISON "$100" FRANKLIN "25 cents or $1" WASHINGTON "$1" EISENHOWER "$1" SACAGAWEA "$20" JACKSON "$50" GRANT "$10" HAMILTON "50 cents" KENNEDY And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/6/2005&g=116&d=A ....

So you're saying for you the question mark was a misdirection?
This is a Friday puzzle; misdirection is totally appropriate.
@Barry Ancona I think he's saying that rather than being a misdirection, it was, to him, a straightforward reading of the clue!

BeeBee,
Who's on first?

@George Krompacky - I don't think "coinage" is ever used to refer to a single coin or specie of coin. It is more of a collective for coins in general. 

You wouldn't show your 1895 Liberty $5 gold piece to a friend, announcing it as "Check out this cool coinage in my collection!" Likewise, you wouldn't refer to a SACAGAWEA DOLLAR as a "cool (or insert your preferred adjective here) coinage." It's a "cool coin." 

The wording of the clue, without the "?", definitely would sound like "coinage" here means "to form a new word."

Hence, the misdirection, and the reason for the question mark. 

Personally, I think the clue would work with or without the question mark, with a slight preference for NOT including it, since this is a Friday puzzle. But it doesn't bother me at all that it is there.

@Barry Ancona We have slightly higher standards for NYT puzzles. This feels like the constructor couldn't think of clever wordplay so just stuck a question mark on the end of a literally worded clue and said "Ha ha! Now it's misleading!"

@EagleAngle

No I don‚Äôt think so. I think they hoped that the solver might guess that that coinage was of the language variety. I didn‚Äôt‚Äîbut it did lead me to consider the possibility which I appreciated.

commentBody:
@Andr√©s
Ah, the dying art of 'setting a nice table'.
When I moved into my very first apartment, the first thing I got was a sofa-bed. The next? A nice set of china. (Marlina by Aynsley, for those who care.) A rudimentary 40-pc. set -- 8 5-piece settings, no soup bowls.
But my mother's fancy set was extensive -- over 125 pieces, I think. Fruit nappies, cream soup and stand, twelve settings plus serving pieces! 
And every fall, we made a regular trek to the warehouse sale by Wm. Ashley & Co., held in the distant exurbs of Toronto, to hunt for missing pieces, replaces losses to breakage, and just look for "nice things".

@SBK My mother loved her bone china and sterling silver.  She would have been hurt to know none of the kids are interested in owning such upper middle class signifiers.  They seem to have gone the way of pearl necklaces, fur coats and, slowly but surely, mined diamonds.

As a constructor who never had to do it the old way, I can‚Äôt compare, nor can I give a rundown of how the masters do it (and I am definitely not one). I will say that most of the crossword creating applications have word lists which can be added to and maintained. Cruciverb.com has word lists that they constantly update and has been invaluable to me. But I know that constructors who are dedicated may add their own words and phrases as well. In addition, those word lists have some ratings for phrases or words that can be tweaked by the users, so good constructors may downgrade entries that they don‚Äôt want to use a lot to make sure their grids are cleaner. Finally, especially for themeless puzzles, good constructors usually find a few good fresh ‚Äúseed‚Äù entries that they want in their puzzles and then use the software to work around those.
